Award.AwardTitle: Virtual Fields Methods for Soft Musculoskeletal Tissue Characterization and Model Validation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Each year hundreds of thousands of people suffer soft tissue injuries. The mechanical properties of the tissues that are damaged are difficult to measure. It is very difficult to make a test specimen from a natural soft tissue because the pre-load in the tissue is lost when it is cut. In addition, the cutting process damages fibers that are essential to the properties. This project will create and apply a method that can measure the deformations of a soft tissue without cutting a specimen and without removing the natural preload. All of the stretch of the tissue is measured using an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) method and the deformations are put into a mathematical model of the tissue to calculate the properties needed to understand how injury occurs. The project will be applied to the anterior cruciate ligament (or ACL) which is part of the knee. Damage or rupture of the ACL is the most common soft tissue injury in athletic individuals. Women are particularly susceptible to ACL injury with rates from 4-10 times that of men depending on which activity. This research will develop new technology for measuring soft tissue mechanical properties and apply it to the ACL. The developed methods will be applicable to other soft, preloaded tissues and also to MRI visible soft engineering materials.

The mechanical properties of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) of the knee are particularly challenging to experimentally characterize; in its anatomically relevant state the ACL is twisted and at least one of its two bundles is partially extended regardless of knee flexion angle. This tissue is also mechanically non-linear, anisotropic, (poro)viscoelastic, and heterogeneous. Full-field displacement methods that provide two- and three- dimensional displacement information over a large surface can reduce the number of test geometries needed to characterize soft tissue, as information about anisotropy, heterogeneity, non-linearity, and even viscoelasticity is contained within the displacement fields. This work seeks to explore full-surface and full-volume imaging modalities with corresponding displacement field analyses as a means to characterize the ACL bundles under uniaxial loading. A constitutive model for the ACL based on the uniaxial loading will be implemented into an MRI-derived finite element framework for computational analysis of the ACL. This model will be validated by using it to predict the ACL response to anterior tibial translation (ATT), its primary failure deformation mode.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanical properties of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) of the knee are particularly challenging to experimentally characterize; in its anatomically relevant state the ACL is twisted and at least one of its two bundles is partially extended regardless of knee flexion angle. This tissue is also mechanically non-linear, anisotropic, (poro)viscoelastic, and heterogeneous. Full-field displacement methods that provide two- and three- dimensional displacement information over a large surface can reduce the number of test geometries needed to characterize soft tissue, as information about anisotropy, heterogeneity, non-linearity, and even viscoelasticity is contained within the displacement fields. In this work we explored full-surface and full-volume imaging modalities with corresponding displacement field analyses as a means to characterize the ACL bundles under uniaxial loading. In particular, we pioneered methods of in-situ MRI based collection of full-field displacement data combined with a virtual fields methods to find a constitutive expression to model the ACL. The MRI-based approach was validated using a surface displacement field measurement technique, digital image correlation (DIC). The ACL material model was implemented into an MRI-derived finite element framework for computational analysis of the ACL and full knee. The importance of accurately describing the soft tissue responses in the full knee models was shown by comparing knee kinematics and tissue level strains in the knee joint with and without ACL non-linearity and anisotropy, and also with and without cartilage spatial heterogeneity.

The experimental techniques developed in this work may be extended to other soft tissues of the body. The advatage of this new approach is its ability to yield far more information about the three-dimensional response of the tissue from a limited number of experiments than could ever be achieved by conventional mechanical test methods.

The intellectual merit of what we achieved with the proposed work is in answering basic mechanics questions about ACL deformation. We've developed an entirely new way to accurately model the non-linear, anisotropic, heterogeneous, viscoelastic response of the ACL for inclusion into in silico models of the knee during impact loading. We have advanced full-field imaging methods and virtual field analysis methods for connective tissue characterization, for the ACL in particular, and for other ligaments and tendons in general.

The broader impacts of the proposed work include various clinically relevant applications of patient-specific simulation tools with improved ACL material models. MRI-derived patient-specific knee models with accurate ACL material descriptions are needed for assessing knee biomechanics, determining ACL injury risk factors, developing training strategies for preventing injuries, and designing better ACL replacement grafts. Clinical outcomes from current ACL replacement surgeries are considered good in terms of restoration of knee stability and the patient’s return to moderate or strenuous physical activities. Mounting evidence, however, suggests current strategies, typically using a patellar tendon or hamstrings tendon graft, substantially alter the biomechanics of the joint. This altered mechanical profile is posited to promote a hazardous mismatch between joint and underlying articular cartilage mechanics driving an increased risk of early onset osteoarthritis (OA). While mechanical factors governing this debilitative progression remain unclear, structural and mechanical inconsistencies between the graft tissue and native ACL are thought to play important roles. Moreover, acute ACL injuries are becoming increasingly prevalent in children as young as 5 years old, which means they have a high likelihood of developing OA in their 20s and living with the debilitating effects of OA for decades before they are candidates for total knee replacements. Graft failure rates are at an unacceptably high level of nearly 25% for the youngest, most active patients (i.e. teens). Accurate models of ACL mechanics and computational tools for assessing knee biomechanics have now been advanced with our work to understand the limitations of current ACT grafts and to design – through e.g. tissue engineering – grafts that do not induce such a high incidence of OA.

An additional broader impact of the project that I am particularly proud of is the number and diversity of the people I was able to train in biomechanics as a result of this grant, either through direct funding or leveraging activities. One person contributed part time to this project as a research scientist. One post-doc wh is a URM contributed significantly to this work. Four PhD students, two of whom are women, two of whom are URMs , and three of whom are NSF fellowship students, worked extensively on this project. Two of the PhD students have graduated and the other two will soon finish up. Finally, several undergraduate students were able to contribute to this project, including several women and URMs. A few are still working with us and others have gone on to PhD programs or medical school!
